instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PCH_SMBALERT_L</SIGNAL> also <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello, i have logic board with shorts on these  <SIGNAL>PCH_SMBALERT_L</SIGNAL> also <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> lines, if apply some current heats CPU. My mission is to take out user data. 

I have same configuration working logic board, what is i would transplant necessary ics? Which ics are married by software?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PCH_SMBALERT_L</SIGNAL> also <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Has anybody faced with data recovery from <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PCH_SMBALERT_L</SIGNAL> also <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I suppose you need to transplant <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8800</CHIP>/01/10 at same time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PCH_SMBALERT_L</SIGNAL> also <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Transplanting the NANDs and controller + ROM sucks balls as they are underfilled. You may be better off trying to replace the CPU first before going the NAND route. But then you have the underfilled RAM next to the CPU too. Unless you can charge $600+ for this I would run away. Don't waste a working board on a low probability of getting data.
